channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: #219 - Hacktoberfest
item.description: This week, Neil -- the mastermind behind the CPAN PR Challenge -- draws our attention on another, new contest organized by Digital Ocean, where one can win a t-shirt by submitting at least 4 pull requests to Open Source projects. He even went above and beyond the call of duty, and provided an addendum to the official and shamefully Perl-devoid list of example projects for the contest. At the other end of the spectrum, Ribashushi is trying something novel: he's organizing a Tilt campaign that would enable him to work on CPAN projects for a full year -- beyond the obvious, it's also quite an interesting idea in the realm of Open Source founding, and I am rather curious to see how it'll develop. Enjoy! ~ `/anick
item.dc:subject: list of tags?

item.title: Perl Dancer book available
item.description: All the Perl Maven articles related to Perl Dancer, now available bundled in one e-book in MOBI format for Kindle.

item.title: Year of ribasushi
item.description: Peter "ribasushi" Rabbitson. knowns (amongst other things) as the maintainer of DBIx::Class, has started a Tilt campaign so he could work a full year on CPAN projects.

item.title: YAPC::NA 2016 Organizers
item.description: Want to be part of the crew behind the event? Here's your chance, YAPC::NA next organizer meeting is a couple of weeks away, and everybody who wants to lend a hand are welcome.

item.title: CPANtoberfest - CPAN projects for hacktoberfest
item.description: Neil draws our attention to Hacktoberfest, a contest where you can get a t-shirt for submitting patches to at least 4 Open Source projects. He also noticed that the official list of suggested Open Source projects is bereft of anything Perlish -- something he couldn't leave unfixed.

item.title: State of the Geek 2015
item.description: Geekuni did a survey on which programming languages its users are mostly working in, and which ones they wishes they'd use more. The results are in.

item.title: A big ol' Catalyst upgrade
item.description: So Ricardo went ahead and upgraded a project stuck with a Catalyst of 2007 vintage. It is a shining badge of honor for the Catalyst crew that this fast-forwarding through 8 years of development went admirably smoothly.

item.title: YAPC::EU 2015 Granada - hiking to Pico del Veleta in Sierra Nevada
item.description: Gabor's report on his trip to Granada. His depiction of the local tapas alone makes me gnash my teeth and bemoans my absensce at the European YAPC.

item.title: What's new on CPAN - September 2015
item.description: David gives us the highlights of what was new and hot on CPAN in September.

item.title: I'm back...
item.description: David is back from an acute bout of travelling, and he's now focusing on documentation. And, in that regard, he asks the floor the question: "what makes for good documentation?"

item.title: Building your own MMDB databases for IP-specific data
item.description: If you are dealing with GeoIP data for websites (or anything else, really), this article is for you. Olaf shows us how to create and query MaxMind's MMDB GeoIP database format.

item.title: Perl5 to Java compiler - integrating with Rhino
item.description: It compiles Perl to Java, which can then call the JavaScript engine. Awe-inspiring or terrifying? I can't really tell.

item.title: Vagrant Perl Development Environment v1.1.0 released
item.description: Not only it's a Perl Development Environment in a box, but Perl 6's rakudo is also included. Nifty!

item.title: 2015.34-40 Birthday!
item.description: All that is happening in the Perl 6 world.

item.title: Those weeks: much progress!
item.description: Perl6. Many progress. Such close to Christmas.

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description:
Great modules released last week;
MetaCPAN weekly report;
StackOverflow Perl report.

item.title: Multiple command line counters with plain TSV text file back-end
Adventure in crawling and scraping the World
